pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:0.5: 2. The training rule on abusive speech
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six were arguing with and abusing good monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.3: They reviled and insulted them about their caste, name, family, work, craft, illnesses, physical traits, defilements, and offenses, and by calling them names.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.4: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.6: “How can the monks from the group of six argue with and abuse good monks?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.7: How can they revile and insult them about these things?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.8: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Master. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.9: “Is it true, monks, that you are acting like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.12: “… Foolish men, how can you argue with and abuse good monks?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.13: How can you revile and insult them about their caste, name, family, work, craft, illnesses, physical traits, defilements, and offenses, and by calling them names?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.14: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.1.16: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.1: “Once upon a time, monks, there was a brahmin in Takkasilā who had an ox called Nandivisāla.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.2: On one occasion the ox said to the brahmin,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.3: ‘Go, brahmin, and make the following bet worth one thousand coins with a prominent merchant:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.4: “My ox will pull one hundred carts tied together.”’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.5: And that brahmin did just that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.7: Then, after tying one hundred carts together and yoking Nandivisāla to them, he said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.9: But Nandivisāla just stood right there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.10: Then that brahmin became depressed because he had lost one thousand coins.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.13: ‘Because I lost one thousand coins because of you.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.14: ‘But why did you disgrace me by calling me a fraud when I’m not?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.15: Now go, brahmin, and make the same bet worth two thousand coins with that merchant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.17: But don’t disgrace me by calling me a fraud.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.18: Once again that brahmin did just that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.20: Then, after tying one hundred carts together and yoking Nandivisāla to them, he said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.22: And Nandivisāla pulled those one hundred carts.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.23: One should say what is pleasant,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.28: And he was delighted with that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.29: Even at that time, monks, reviling and insulting was unpleasant to me.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.30: How then could reviling and insulting be pleasant now?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.31: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.32: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:1.2.33: ‘If a monk speaks abusively, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.2: he abuses in ten ways: about caste, about name, about family, about work, about craft, about illnesses, about physical traits, about defilements, about offenses, and by insulting.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.5: there are two kinds of castes: low castes and high castes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.8: outcasts, bamboo workers, hunters, chariot-makers, waste-removers— these are called “low castes.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.11: aristocrats and brahmins— these are called “high castes.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.14: there are two kinds of names: low names and high names.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.17: Avakaṇṇaka, Javakaṇṇaka, Dhaniṭṭhaka, Saviṭṭhaka, Kulavaḍḍhaka, or names, in whatever countries, that are despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded— these are called “low names.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.20: those connected with the Buddha, connected with the Teaching, or connected with the Order, or names, in whatever countries, that are highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed— these are called “high names.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.23: there are two kinds of families: low families and high families.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.26: the Kosiya family, the Bhāradvāja family, or families, in whatever countries, that are despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded— these are called “low families.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.29: the Gotama family, the Moggallāna family, the Kaccāna family, the Vāsiṭṭha family, or families, in whatever countries, that are highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed— these are called “high families.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.32: there are two kinds of work: low work and high work.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.35: carpentry, waste-removing, or work, in whatever countries, that is despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded— this is called “low work.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.38: farming, trade, cattle-keeping, or work, in whatever countries, that is highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed— this is called “high work.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.41: there are two kinds of crafts: low crafts and high crafts.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.44: reed-work, pottery, weaving, leather-work, hairdressing, or crafts, in whatever countries, that are despised, looked down upon, scorned, treated with contempt, disregarded— these are called “low crafts.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.47: calculating, accounting, writing, or crafts, in whatever countries, that are highly regarded, highly thought of, respected, valued, esteemed— these are called “high crafts.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.50: all are low, but there is the disease of diabetes which is high.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.52: there are two kinds of physical traits: low physical traits and high physical traits.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.55: too tall, too short, too dark, too fair— these are called “low physical traits.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.58: not too tall, not too short, not too dark, not too fair— these are called “high physical traits.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.63: all are low, but there is the attainment of stream-entry which is high.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.65: there are two kinds of insults: low insults and high insults.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.68: “you’re a camel/you’re a ram/you’re an ox/you’re a donkey/you’re an animal/you’re bound for hell; you’re not going to a good destination/you can only expect a bad destination,” or adding the disparaging endings _ya_ or _bha_ to someone’s name, or calling someone words for the male and female genitals— these are called “low insults.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.1.72: “you’re wise/you’re competent/you’re intelligent/you’re learned/you’re an expounder of the Teaching; you’re not going to a bad destination/you can only expect a good destination”— these are called “high insults.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2:2.2.1: If one who is fully ordained, wishing to revile, wishing to insult, wishing to humiliate another who is fully ordained, says what is low to one who is low—an outcast/a bamboo worker/a hunter/a chariot-maker/a waste-remover— saying, “You’re an outcast/you’re a bamboo worker/you’re a hunter/you’re a chariot-maker/you’re a waste-remover,” then for every statement, he commits an offense entailing confession.
